11: Either an established or young colony.
24: A research station or remote military outpost.
31: An enemy ship, or perhaps an abandoned ship.
33: A transfer station, space colony or orbital survey platform.
35: Far from civilization, a remote spot on a planetary surface.
41: An active war zone, fought between colonies, corporations or nation states, with ruined buildings, wrecked vehicles and fortifications.
44: A landing field far from any colony, owned by a corporation, individual or military.
51: Colonial farmsteads, far from civilization and scattered across the planetary surface.
53: A huge mining and refining complex, with hundreds of workers and executives.
56: Remote penal colony, housing hardened and violent inmates.
62: An automated sensor site, perhaps with its own defenses.
64: Harsh, inhospitable wilderness such as thick jungle, deep caverns or volcanic lava fields.

11: Scout a location, gather intelligence and then report back.
14: Attack and hold an objective by force.
16: Defend a location/person/group and repel any attack until relieved or until a set time.
22: Patrol an area, looking for signs of the enemy.
24: Infiltrate an enemy location and destroy a key asset (bridge, uplink tower, radar dish, etc.)
31: Create chaos and destruction by attacking targets of opportunity behind enemy lines.
33: Search for a downed pilot, lost colonists, etc.
36: Quell a riot and re-establishing order, or protect lines of communication and essential services until authority can be restored.
43: Exterminate local alien life that is threatening colonists on an off-world planet.
51: A colonial or space station population needs immediate rescue from a crisis or natural catastrophe.
53: A space station, orbital platform or starship must be captured (or recaptured) by boarding it and seizing control.
55: The marines are aboard a military vessel that makes customs and security checks on civilian ships in the area, looking for illegal drugs or other goods, arms, workers being trafficked etc.
56: Locate and seize an item, person or group from behind enemy lines. It may be hostages, POWs, an enemy commander or a piece of high technology.
63: A station, colony or installation is not responding to Network communications. Investigate.

11: The marines find out that the bad guys are actually good guys.
13: During the mission, the marines may find themselves saddled with enemy prisoners or innocent civilians that they must now guard/protect.
16: The team is saddled with a reporter/cameraman or a senior officer who gets in the way and asks stupid questions.
21: A corporate representative joins the team and is there to ensure the company’s assets and interests are protected.
24: Technical knowledge or on-site advice is provided by a civilian advisor who has little knowledge of military operations. They may get scared or panic easily.
26: An NPC or even a PC is captured by hostile forces.
33: The team has faulty gear. It could be anything from ammo or weapons to sensors or vehicles.
41: The opponents are far tougher and more ruthless than expected.
45: During the mission, the team discovers that it is completely trapped, either physically, or tactically.
51: The mission location is hit by an air-strike, mines, or heavy weapons, possibly the result of a mishap by their own forces!
54: A new commanding office, a lieutenant, is keen to get himself a medal or commendation, and pushes the marine squad into perilous situations. Someone is going to get killed!
56: There are hidden dangers across the mission site, varying with the nature of the location. They may be mines, IEDs, predatory carnivorous plants or improvised booby traps.
63: There are tactical restrictions placed on the mission—how the squad acts, where it can go, what weapons it can use, etc.
65: A new platoon commander is a green, untested and untried lieutenant. He’s read the books, survived the training and ran the simulations—but he’ll go to pieces once the bullets start flying.
